newsitem.title: GERMANY: German shares head into holiday in stable form.
newsitem.headline: German shares head into holiday in stable form.

text.p: German shares were broadly stable in late electronic trade on Wednesday, regaining their composure following a downward dip on stronger-than-expected U.S. economic growth data.
"The market seems to be holding up well against shocks from the U.S. at the moment," said one dealer. "I think the 3,400 (DAX points) level is pretty well secured."

The IBIS DAX index was up 6.22 points at 3,432.08 points at 1404 GMT, having dipped to a low of 3,416.11 points after the early afternoon release of data showing 5.6 percent growth in U.S. GDP in the first quarter.
Dealers said activity was extremely quiet ahead of the May 1 German public holiday on Thursday, during which the German share market will be closed.
Futures were dominating activity, dealers said, with little real movement on the cash market.
"People are just establishing themselves in reasonably safe waters. There is always the fear that there will be major developments while we are closed," a Munich dealer said.
The June DTB DAX future was up 15 points at 3,446 points in afternoon trade. Gains were helped by the firm dollar, always a boon for Germany's export firms.
Some dealers were optimistic that the market was well positioned to break out of its current lethargy.
More dividend payouts are expected in the coming weeks, which should boost liquidity as investors reinvest the payouts.

Chemical giant Bayer AG, trading ex-dividend, was down three marks, or over four percent at 67.20 marks. BASF AG, under pressure earlier after slightly disappointing first quarter results, was up 1.05 marks at 67.45 marks.
Electronics and engineering giant Siemens AG continued its recent run of popularity, fuelled by technical buy signals, to trade up 88 pfennigs at 93.93 marks.
Car shares were also performing well, with Volkswagen AG up 30.5 marks, or 2.9 percent, at 1,098 marks.
Bayerische Motoren Werke AG was up 28.50 marks, or two percent, at 428.50 marks.
